Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Exoneration and Compensation: The Role of False Confessions

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Instances in which innocent individuals are wrongly convicted represent serious travesties of justice because the actual guilty offenders may go on to commit other, sometimes serious, crimes and the wrongly convicted innocents languish in prison for years (on average, over 13 years for serious crimes). The processes involved with exonerating innocent individuals of wrongful convictions is not well understood. Essential factors and aids necessary to facilitate these innocents’ well-being and reintegration into society upon exoneration are even less understood. A growing body of research has demonstrated that, although all of these individuals are innocent, (a) the process to exoneration differs depending on the circumstances associated with the wrongful conviction (such as whether the person falsely confessed) and (b) the general public still perceives these individuals as not entirely innocent, not entirely deserving of reintegration aids such as job training and counseling, and less fit for office jobs. A better understanding of the processes involved with exoneration attempts and a deeper appreciation of the compensation and aids necessary to more fully make these innocent individuals whole is critical to informing and developing statutes and reforms that will facilitate their reintegration into society.

Although our legal system has witnessed a proliferation of exonerations for wrongful convictions across the last decade or two, the process leading to exoneration and the aftereffects of being exonerated are not well understood. Differences in the process leading to exoneration, types and degree of aid, and timeliness of receiving aids have all been documented. Given that innocent confessors suffer a series of cumulative disadvantages during their journey through the legal system, this project will examine the idea that innocent confessors have particularly onerous experiences. To address this idea, the project will use in-depth interviews with attorneys who have worked on exoneration cases, exonerees (who have and have not falsely confessed), and innocence advocates to examine structural-level (e.g., wrongful conviction in a compensation statute state or not; exonerated with assistance from an innocence project); case-level (e.g., false confession or not); and individual-level (e.g., exoneration status, race) factors that influence whether an exoneree receives no, partial, or full compensation, and the types of compensation to explore how these aids (or lack of) impact post-conviction well-being and reentry adjustment. The in-depth interviews are complemented with an experimental field study of thousands of employers in five locations, comparing their willingness to hire exonerees who did and did not falsely confess, guilty paroled offenders, and those with no criminal history. The findings have the potential to illustrate barriers to exoneree compensation, determine how receipt of compensation and aid (type and amount) can influence post-exoneration re-entry experiences, and causally demonstrate the obstacles exonerees face when attempting to find employment. The ultimate goal is to inform state and federal compensation statutes, leading states without statutes to adopt ones or states with statutes to revise their current ones—such as removing controversial restrictions around false confessions, including employment assistance to help exonerees better adjust, and other aids that many exonerees desire but rarely can access.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Wrongful convictions represent egregious travesties of justice. Although being exonerated of a wrongful conviction ostensibly brings freedom to these individuals, a growing body of literature shows that individuals who have been wrongly convicted confront obstacles that hinder their ability to successfully reintegrate. Such barriers to reintegration may include obtaining financial compensation for their wrongful conviction and securing employment. Moreover, emerging research suggests that individuals wrongly convicted based on a false confession may face additional barriers to reintegration. In this collaborative research, we conducted a multi-method investigation of compensation and reintegration efforts among individuals wrongly convicted. Specifically, through in-depth interviews, we examined the process for receiving financial compensation, the outcomes of that process, and the post-release experiences of exonerees who did and did not (at least in some cases, yet) receive such assistance. In addition, through a field experiment, we tested if individuals who were wrongly convicted were more disadvantaged post-exoneration in terms of finding employment than guilty paroled offenders and those with no criminal history, and whether the contributing factor to the wrongful convicting and severity of the crime impacted employment prospects.

To address these questions, the project included two phases. In Phase I, we conducted 43 semi-structured interviews with individuals wrongly convicted who did or did not (yet) receive financial compensation, civil attorneys who assist with compensation cases, and innocence advocates (e.g., social workers) who aid in the reintegration process. In brief, we found that the compensation process and its outcomes can both hinder and facilitate exonerees’ overall reintegration. For instance, the high bar of proving innocence in civil cases can feel like another form of victimization for some exonerees. Further, delays to compensation can force exonerees to rely on others and hinder their independence, yet compensation without proper financial literacy training can lead to unsustainable spending habits among compensated exonerees. However, the compensation process can also facilitate independence and healing by providing exonerees the ability to regain control, acknowledging the harms inflicted on them, and validating their innocence. In addition, interviewees suggested that false confessions are associated with biases that may influence exonerees’ compensation and reintegration efforts. Specifically, false confessions can disadvantage exonerees’ compensation attempts through, for example, the presence of contributory provisions in state statutes or disbelief in false confessions among triers-of-fact. However, under certain circumstances, false confessions can advantage exonerees’ compensation attempts if, for example, it is paired with strong evidence of police misconduct.

In Phase II, we conducted a national correspondence-audit experiment to investigate the effect of wrongful conviction on employment prospects. We submitted fictitious applications to 15,579 entry-level jobs posted on an online job board and tracked positive responses (e.g., interview requests) from potential employers. We found evidence of hiring discrimination against individuals wrongly convicted. Specifically, wrongly convicted applicants, regardless of whether their wrongful conviction involved a false confession or eyewitness misidentification, received significantly fewer positive responses than the applicants with no legal system involvement. Further, positive response rates among wrongly convicted applicants were not significantly different from the guilty offenders, and the severity of the crime (manslaughter vs. drug charge) did not affect positive response rates from potential employers.

Regarding intellectual merit, the knowledge gains carry implications for several areas of empirical inquiry. First, findings from Phase I provide an in-depth understanding of the exoneree compensation process from multiple perspectives, as well as add to the empirical literature on the potential disadvantages that false confessors experience relative to exonerees wrongly convicted for other reasons. Second, the correspondence-audit study in Phase II further advances our understanding of the possible stigma surrounding wrongful conviction, generally, and false confessions, specifically. The results from the present work provide robust evidence that exonerees face hiring discrimination on the job market relative to individuals with no legal system involvement.

Regarding broader impact, the findings from both phases have implications for practices and policies aimed at assisting exonerees after wrongful convictions. Our results suggest that exonerees face both barriers and delays to compensation and discrimination on the job market—factors that can meaningfully hinder their path to successful reintegration and can influence their ability to heal from the injustices suffered. Our findings also inform state and federal compensation statutes, indicating specific aids that should be included in policies from states without statutes and reforms for states with statutes to better address the needs of this population. For example, findings could serve as grounds to amend statutes with controversial restrictions around false admissions, including employment assistance and other aids that many exonerees desire but often cannot access.
